MEMBERS OP THE BOARD ADAM McMULLEN Governor FRANK MARSH Secretary of State L. B. JOHNSON State Auditor W. M. STEBBINS State Treasurer T. E. WILLIAMS State Tax Commissioner TAX COMMISSIONERS OF NEBRASKA The position of State Tax Commissioner was created by the constitu - tion of 1920. Prior thereto the work was performed by a secretary to the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, the Tax Commis - sioner being made a member of the board. Those who have served as Commissioner under the constitutional provision are: NAME COUNTY SERVED W. H. OSBORNE Custer WM. H. SMITH Seward T. E. WILLIAMS Hamilton April 25, 1921, to April 18, 1923 April 18, 1923, to Jan. 12, 1925 Jan. 12, 1925, to

LETTER OP TRANSMITTA1, December 15, 1927 Hon. Adam McMullen, Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln. My dear Sir: Herewith is transmitted the annual report of this department for the year 1927. In doing so I want to express the appreciation of the department for the co-operation of yourself and the other members of the State Board of Equalization and Assessment. I also want to express my thanks to the County Assessors and County Clerks of the state for their help, and to the other county officers upon whom it has been necessary to make frequent calls for co-operation. Yours very truly, T. E. WILLIAMS, State Tax Commissioner.

62 REPORT OP TAX COMMISSIONER STATEMENT NO. 2 Intangible Property All property of this kind is divided into two classes "A" and "B". Class "A" is lade up of all kinds of money and is taxable at the rate of 2>/, mills on the dollar. Class "B" is made up of all other kinds of intangible property and is taxable at the rate of 5 mills on the dollar. The total amount of Class A returned for taxation for the year is $65,076,652 and the total amount of Class B is $77,159,220. REPORT OF TAX COMMISSIONER 72 STATEMENT NO. 8 ASSESSMENT OF RAILROAD COMPANIES In 1921 the Chicago and Northwestern and the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha R. R. Companies were permitted under an order of the United States District Court to pay 75% and 60% of their assessments, respectively. A special master in chancery was appointed and testimony taken in regard to their valuation as well as to the valuation of other property, more particularly real estate. It was finally decided by the Master and affirmed by the Court that these companies were over-assessed and that other properties were assessed at only 70% of their actual value. The finding was appealed by the State to the United States Supreme Court and this Court affirmed the decision of the lower court. In the meantime, similar actions were commenced each year by the above-named roads for the years 1922, 1923, 1924, 1925 and 1926, and by the Chicago, Burlington & Quincy for the years 1922, 1923, 1924, 1925 and 1926; by The Missouri Pacific Railroad Cor - poration in Nebraska for the years 1924, 1925 and 1926; The Chicago. Rock Island, Pacific Railroad Company for the years 1925 and 1926. For each of these years, under an order of the United States District Court these Companies were permitted to with-hold 25% of their taxes. The C. St. P. M. & O. was permitted to with-hold 40%. Special masters in chancery were appointed by the Court to take testimony in regard to the valuation of the companies as well as the valuation of other property. The testimony for the years 1922, 1923 and 1924 has all been submitted but no decision at this time has been given. An attempt was made by a Legislative Committee to settle these suits during the Legislative Session of 1927 but it was not successful. The Legislature, however, did enact a law which provided that the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, in making these assess - ments, should show how it arrived at the valuation of the various com - panies. This the Board did and the same is submitted on the follow - ing pages. The new law also provided for a direct appeal from the action of the State Board to the Supreme Court of Nebraska. None of the various companies elected to take an appeal from the action of the State Board to the Supreme Court but the Chicago, Burlington & Quincy and Rock Island commenced an action in the Federal Court during the latter part of November and an injunction was granted on November 30, 1927 permitting the Burlington to pay 87.35% of the taxes assessed against it and the Rock Island was permitted to pay 84 % of the taxes levied against it.

STATE OF NEBRASKA 73 In making the assessment df railroad companies the State Board attempted to follow the new law to the letter and this resulted in reducing the assessment of all railroad property about forty million dollars. All of the railroad companies with the exception of the Burlington and Rock Island, have indicated their satisfaction with the 1927 assessment and are praying the full amount of the 1927 taxes levied against them. The Missouri Pacific has gone further than any of the others by offering to pay their 1924, 1925 and 1926 taxes on the same basis as the 1927 assessment which offer was acceptable to the federal court and on November 30, 1927, a decree to this effect was made by the court. The Missouri Pacific at this time is paying these taxes and the decree will result in their paying about 150,000 into the different county treasuries for the years 1924, 1925 and 1926. The order made by the State Board in making this assessment is submitted herewith. Governor's Office State House Lincoln, Nebraska July 22, 1927. The State Board of Equalization and Assessment reconvened, after recess, for the further consideration of the assessment of the prop - erties of the several railroad companies in the State of Nebraska, all members of the Board being present. After considering all of the evidence submitted by the several rail - road companies and all of the additional evidence before the Board it was moved by Tax Commissioner Williams and seconded by Treas - urer Stebbins that the following resolution relating to the assessment of railroads be adopted: WHEREAS, this Board made an order on July 11, 1927, assessing and valuing the properties of the several railroad companies in the State of Nebraska, and WHEREAS, it has been shown conclusively that certain errors were made in making said assessment THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED that the order of assessment made on July 11, 1927, be amended to read as follows: The State Board of Equalization and Assessment in regular ses - sion held for the purpose of valuing, assessing and equalizing the

74 REPORT OF TAX COMMISSIONER properties of the several railroad companies in Nebraska for the pur- pose of taxation for the current year and having given due and full consideration to the returns furnished to this Board by the several railroad companies and all of the additional evidence furnished by the several railroad companies, both oral and documentary, and to all of the evidence offered by the attorney general and to all the evidence offered by this Board upon its own motion, all of which evidence, with the objections thereto, is duly embodied in the record thereof in this office, and after having fully considered the arguments of counsel for the several railroad companies and being duly advised and informed in the premises, the Board finds the full actual value and the equalized value of the properties of the several railroad companies, respectively, for the year 1927, as follows: CHICAGO, BURLINGTON & QUIXCY RAILROAD COMPANY The actual value of the property of the Chicago, Burlington & Quincy Railroad Company in Nebraska is found by considering the market value of the stocks and bonds of the system as of April 1, 1927, the net earnings of the system as reported to the Interstate Commerce Commission for the year 1926 capitalized at 5%% and the physical value as found by the Interstate Commerce Commission as of June 30, 1917, with net additions and betterments to December 31, 1926. ST. JOSEPH AND GRAND ISLAND RAILROAD COMPANY The stock of the St. Joseph and Grand Island Railroad Company is all owned by the Union Pacific with the exception of 1.44%. This stock is not listed on the stock exchange and the only sales we were able to find were a few shares which were bought by the Union Pacific about a year ago. These sales run from $16.50 per share to $43.00 per share. Inasmuch as the market value of the stocks and bonds and the net earnings of this company do not reflect the actual value, thi3 value is computed on the amount found by the Interstate Com - merce Commission as of June 30, 1919, together with net additions and betterments to December 31, 1926, plus 25%, for increased land values and increased unit costs. The different items used to arrive at the physical value as of this date are as follows: Interstate Commerce Commission value as of June 30, 1919, with net additions and betterments to December 31, 1926, for the system. % 7,740,404 Plus 25% for increased lands and increased unit costs 1,936,801 TOTAL $ 9,677,205 Allocation The percentage at which the all track mileage in Nebraska bears to the all track mileage of the system is 43.65%. Allocating the $9,677,205 on this basis gives $4,224,099 as Nebraska's share of the actual value of this road.
